scenarios.title: The Bill of Rights Debate
scenarios.description: It's 1789. As a key advisor to the first Congress, you must decide whether to push for the Bill of Rights.

choices.text: Push for the Bill of Rights
choices.outcome: You successfully add the Bill of Rights, ensuring individual liberties are protected.
The Constitution is ratified without the Bill of Rights, leading to future controversies.

scenarios.title: Civil Rights Era
scenarios.description: It's 1964. The President is considering signing the Civil Rights Act. As an advisor, you must weigh the impact on constitutional rights.

choices.outcome: The act is signed, leading to significant progress in civil rights.
The act is delayed, causing prolonged social unrest and criticism.

scenarios.title: Modern Privacy Concerns
scenarios.description: It's 2024. The government is debating new surveillance laws. Your role is to advise on the balance between security and privacy.

choices.outcome: Increased security but potential privacy concerns arise.
Privacy is protected but security measures are less stringent.

scenarios.title: The Louisiana Purchase Decision
scenarios.description: It's 1803. President Thomas Jefferson is considering the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France. As an advisor, you must decide whether to support the purchase.

choices.outcome: The purchase is approved, doubling the size of the United States and securing valuable resources and land.
The purchase is halted, leaving the U.S. with limited expansion opportunities and missing out on valuable resources.

scenarios.title: The War of 1812 Strategy
scenarios.description: It's 1812. The U.S. is at war with Britain. As a military strategist, you must decide on a key strategy to win the war.

choices.outcome: Emphasize naval battles, which leads to notable victories on the seas but struggles on land.
Concentrate on land campaigns, leading to significant battles but also suffering defeats at sea.

scenarios.title: The Emancipation Proclamation
scenarios.description: It's 1862. President Abraham Lincoln is deciding whether to issue the Emancipation Proclamation, which would declare the freedom of slaves in Confederate states. As an advisor, what will you recommend?

choices.outcome: The proclamation is issued, shifting the focus of the Civil War to abolition and strengthening the Union's moral position.
The proclamation is delayed, potentially prolonging the war and continuing the division between North and South.

scenarios.title: The New Deal
scenarios.description: It's 1933. President Franklin D. Roosevelt is considering implementing the New Deal to address the Great Depression. As an advisor, what will you recommend?

choices.outcome: The New Deal is implemented, providing immediate relief to millions and reforming the economy, but facing opposition from various quarters.
The New Deal is delayed, resulting in prolonged economic hardship and increased public unrest.
